title: The Starry Night
description: The Starry Night is an oil-on-canvas painting by the Dutch Post-Impressionist painter Vincent van Gogh. Painted in June 1889, it depicts the view from the east-facing window of his asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, just before sunrise, with the addition of an imaginary village.
the_art: Van Gogh depicted the view at different times of the day and under various weather conditions, such as the sunrise, moonrise, sunshine-filled days, overcast days, windy days, and one day with rain.

title: Panning in the Reeds
description: The Artwork is a characteristic example of Hernan Bas’ large-scale landscapes, which are typically executed in vivid color palettes using the artist’s signature stylized formality, and often featuring androgynous young male figures. The Artwork is an example of Bas' signature style, with its bold brushstrokes, romanticized depiction of youth and bright colors such as blue, green and white.
the_art: The Artwork shows a small figure in the center of the work, the young man standing in water. He is holding an object that emits rays. The rays draw our eyes to the top left of the painting, where we see a chariot pulled by two white horses. This may be a reference to the Greek god Helios, the sun god.

title: Kenju
description: The Artwork is a dynamic example of Kazuo Shiraga’s signature black and red Gutai paintings.
the_art: Kazuo Shiraga’s action-based painting technique conceptually links him to the famous Abstract Expressionist Jackson Pollock. In fact, Pollock owned a copy of the Gutai group manifesto, which was found amongst his papers when he died in 1956. Red and black are Kazuo Shiraga’s favorite colors to paint with, making the Artwork an especially desirable example of the artist’s oeuvre.

title: Greed and Greed 1
description: Christine Ay Tjoe’s paintings from 2016 illustrate a stylistic shift in the artist’s expressionist painting practice towards more pictorial compositions with dynamic allusions to violent and infernal motifs, such as organs, demons, claws, and limbs.
the_art: The Artwork illustrates an injured demon in Christine Ay Tjoe’s expressionist painting style. The dragon-like creature emerges from sheer washes of green and brown paint delineated by angular sketched lines. Bursts of red paint and the demon’s pained, open-mouth expression highlight the violence present in the image.

title: Untitled
description: The Artwork exemplifies Adrian Ghenie’s haunting hybridization of representation and abstraction inspired by his dual interest in old master painting and Abstract Expressionism. This formal tension reflects Ghenie’s controversial subject matter, which seeks to understand people’s mindsets in dark moments of social tumult.
the_art: The Artwork oscillates between representation and abstraction. Adrian Ghenie strategically paints brushstrokes to delineate a glass coffee table with a red couch behind it in the foreground of a warmly lit, neutral brown interior. Two disembodied socked legs sit on the couch, and exaggerated swaths of pale, fleshy pigment replace the figure’s torso. The upper half of the canvas explodes into a completely abstract collection of gestural red, brown, white, gray and black brushstrokes.

title: The Persistence of Memory
description: Hard objects become inexplicably limp in this bleak and infinite dreamscape, while metal attracts ants like rotting flesh. Mastering what he called “the usual paralyzing tricks of eye-fooling,” Dalí painted with “the most imperialist fury of precision,” he said, but only “to systematize confusion and thus to help discredit completely the world of reality.” It is the classic Surrealist ambition, yet some literal reality is included, too: the distant golden cliffs are the coast of Catalonia, Dalí’s home.
the_art: The well-known surrealist piece introduced the image of the soft melting pocket watch.[2] It epitomizes Dalí's theory of 'softness' and 'hardness', which was central to his thinking at the time. As Dawn Adès wrote, 'The soft watches are an unconscious symbol of the relativity of space and time, a Surrealist meditation on the collapse of our notions of a fixed cosmic order'.

title: Salvator Mundi
description: Salvator Mundi is a painting attributed in whole or in part to the Italian High Renaissance artist Leonardo da Vinci, dated to c. 1499–1510. The painting was sold in 2017 for US$ 450,3 millions, making it the most valuable painting in the world
the_art: The painting depicts Jesus Christ in an anachronistic blue Renaissance dress, making the sign of the cross with his right hand, while holding a transparent, non-refracting crystal orb in his left, signaling his role as Salvator Mundi and representing the 'celestial sphere' of the heavens.

title: Pollo Frito
description: Executed in 1982, an extremely influential period for the artist, the Painting brings together key elements of the artist’s influential style, including direct references to popular culture and a pithy use of language. Edge to edge, the Painting is unmistakably hot, not unlike fried chicken. Spanning twelve feet across both canvases—the orange, yellow, and red brushstrokes evoke an incendiary sensation.
the_art: Basquiat’s iconic crown can be spotted on the top left corner of the canvas. The crown is used frequently across the Artist’s work and is thought to signify the duality of his self-image; both as a king of the world and the human suffering insinuated by the crown of thorns.

title: Untitled (Saturday Night)
description: The Artwork is created in Avery Singer’s unique airbrushed, geometric style. To achieve this style, the artist digitally drafts an image in Google SketchUp and then projects it onto a large-scale canvas to hand-paint using masking tape and an airbrush.
the_art: The Artwork is a portrait of a seated woman created in Avery Singer’s signature style and a muted, predominantly grayscale palette. The inclusion of “Saturday Night” in the title of the work suggests the image might illustrate the malaise of a young woman out and alone on a Saturday night.

title: The End of Baroque
description: The Artwork is an impressive and rare large-scale painting by Liu Ye. Less than 30 paintings similar in scale by Liu Ye have appeared at public auction throughout his career, and they make up seven out of his top ten auction records.
the_art: The title of the work, The End of Baroque, also acknowledges the period of transition taking place in Liu Ye’s life and art. The artist moves away from his early fascination with Baroque art, a seventeenth-century movement characterized by its ornate style, religious iconography, and allegorical themes.

title: View of Rhenen
description: Jan van Goyen composed this grand, visually compelling panorama of Rhenen, a medieval walled city on the Rhine River, in 1646. Situating the viewer near the winding road that leads to the city, he masterfully captured the overarching sky, undulating terrain, and vast sweeps of Dutch countryside for which that region was known.
the_art: This panoramic landscape is so grand and visually compelling that one can almost imagine traveling down the winding road that leads to Rhenen, a medieval walled city on the Rhine River.
